hints.content:
If the limits of integration $a$ and $b$ in a definite integral

$\displaystyle \int_a^b f(x) \,dx$

are both *finite* and the integrand $f$ is *continuous* on the interval of integration $[a,b]$, the integral is **proper**.

If at least one of the limits of integration is *infinite*, or if the integrand is discontinuous because it has a *singularity* in the interval of integration, the integral is **improper**.

hints.content:
The graph of the integrand

$f(x)=\dfrac1{x-1}$

has a vertical asymptote at $x=1$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/25b4d51af53825accaa4ea536cd26a8e388d8a0e)

This tells us the integrand $f$ has a singularity at the point $1$.

The first integral

$\displaystyle \int_{2}^{3}\dfrac1{x-1}\,dx$

has interval of integration $[2,3]$. The interval excludes the point $1$ where the integrand has a singularity.

**The first integral is proper.**

The second integral

$\displaystyle \int_{1}^{3}\dfrac1{x-1}\,dx$

has lower limit $1$. The integrand has a singularity at $1$.

**The second integral is improper.**

The third integral

$\displaystyle \int_{-1}^{3}\dfrac1{x-1}\,dx$

has interval of integration $[-1,3]$, which contains the point $1$. The integrand has a singularity at $1$.

**The third integral is improper.**
